bibl.title: SEVENTH BIENNIAL REPORT OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF THE NORFOLK HOSPITAL FOR INSANE TO THE GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA. FOR THE TWO YEARS ENDING NOVEMBER 30, 1900.

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

SEVENTH BIENNIAL REPORT
SUPERINTENDENT
r th
Norfolk Hospital for Insane
TO TH
GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA
FOR THE TWO YEARS ENDING NOVEMBER 30. 1900.
LINCOLN, NEE

BOARD OF CONTROL.

REPORT.
the Hon. William A. Poynter, Governor of the State of Nebraska.
Snt: I have I lie honor to herewith submit for vour considera
linn the report of I lie condition and management of the Norfolk Hospital for Insane during the seventh biennial period ending November :{(!. l'HMI.
Mv appointment as superintendent of this hospital took effect
July 1. mini, succeeding l>r. (i. F. Keiper; his resignation tak iny effed on that date.
There were remaining on the records of the hospital at the
al 24s. Actual number in hospital December 1. 1898, md 7(1 females; total 241. New cases admitted to
November .SO. l'MMl. 1,4 males and !)1 females; total 2t>5. Total
I males and l»i!> females; total 508. Trans-
Hastings. 32 males and (i females; total .">*. Discharged
lies and ."><; females; total 14!». Discharged
ox. <l. 1 male and 1 female: total 2. Home on parole. 1
ale and on.- female; total 2. Died, li males and 15 females;
Heiuaining on record
November 31), l'.MMl. 17i males and number in hospital November :»0,
»•"! fenia
il 270. Actual
!!»»)(>. 174 males and !»1 femal
total 2»»5. Daily average 184
nales; total 20!
ECOVKKI
hundred and forty-nine recoveries during the
w i
or 2!i.4:: per cent of the whole number under i.v fair average when taken into consideration
number of resident incurables
lefiiniiin;; of the bieiinium. Dei-ember 1, lf<!t!S. 174 males and 74 '(•males; tutal 1'4N. Actual immliei- in lirwinitsil I). inlw.i- i wu«

240
LAXU COMMI88IOXBR 8 KKPORT.
HKATI1 BATE.
There were thirty-two deaths daring the period, a percentage of <>.31 of the whole number treated: one. a suicidal, the coroner was notified, held an inquest, and the verdict rendered exonerated the hospital management from blame. Four of the deaths were patient** admitted in a state of prostration, who were old and in such poor physical health lhal they could not rally from their afflictions, one patient having attained the age of SJ years. The hospital during the last biennial has had a large number of incurable insane, and we have been fortunate in having no
epidemic or typhoid fever. The hospital has a well-kept cemetery where patients are buried, upon request of friends, their graves* marked by head-stones with name, age and date of death: one ot the pastors of the city conducting the services at the grave.
HAl'KI, SKKVICK. AMI S KM K NTS ASH RKCREAT
The chapel services have been held here regularly and I he d orum and attention of the patients is excellent: the clergynit
of the city kindly taking tutus in conducting the services. The usual diversions have been employed for the amusement and entertainment i»f the patients. Our weekly dance with music l>,\ our excellent orchestra has been a source of much pleasure and benefit to the patients. We have also had many miscellaneous •entertainments, which have been enjoyed by all. The employ
•ompulsorv. we seek to induce it the extent of health and benefit
meut is varied and. while not by kindness and persuasion t< of the patient. The male pati ?•hen. laundrv and farm wort
nts assist in the ward work, ki The female patients assist i
ihe ward work, kitchen, laundry and sewing room
TRANSKKU III HASTIN
¦i
I M
IROXI
During the biennial period there were, by order of the Board
<it Public Lands and Buildings, two transfers of patients to tht
Asylum for Chronic Insane at Hastings: the Hist transf
males, made .Inlv Is. IS'.in. the second of "-!:! males and

XE HOSI'ITAI
NORFOLK
241
I

i
I
J
I
Marcl
•0(1; a total of 5i< during the biennial
n-iod. The transfers were made over the F. E. & M. V. K. R.
us for the occasion.
I'ER CAPITA COST OK MAINTENANCE.
lie per capita cost, based on the daily average of 26!) patients
ie last biennial ending November 30, 1900, calculated on the
•ntire amount of appropriations expended, is $3.48 per week. I'lie dailv per capita is 4S cents per patient — the lowest per apita in the history of the institution: the patients being well
(1 and well clothed.
IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED.
riie need for better tire protection by the erection of a large ¦el stand pipe is quite necessary, as the wooden tank is old and ly holds 4.~)0 barrels and is insufficient in case of fire; an ad ion:;] steam pump for the outside well should be purchased, that in case of accident to one pump or well, no inconvenience
Olllll
from lack of water
»
AND KEPRKSERATING PLANT
The hospital is very much in need of an ice and refrigerating lant for the proper care of meats, vegetables, and butter, as the resent ice house is practically useless and its storage capacity nail. The cost of putting up ice yearly, and haviug no proper lace for keeping meat, butter, etc.. makes it very necessary for refrigerating and cold-storage plant, which would be a great iving to th« institution and enable us to keep meats, vegetables, id butter on hand without fear of spoiling.
A I
IKY
The improvement needed in the laundry is a new steam washer, one has become very much worn and will soon be useless. A nibined shirt and collar ironer would add much to the efti•iic.v of the work in the laundrv.

•
242
I.AXL) i-ilMMlSSIONKi: S
HEI'llKT.
NECESSITY fok MOKE LAND.
I wish to again repeat the necessity for more laud, as the laud
beloiifiinji to the hospital is poor and Bandy and not very pro
dnctive; an additional NO a< res should be purchased so that tht
stock will have plenty of pasture and the hospital needs better
provided for by having more and better land for garden. It has
been necessary to rent 40 acres near the hospital, of which 10
Hies was cultivated in sugar beets, which paid the rent and left
a surplus. With the remaining 34) acres cultivated in vegetables
affords us sufficient needs for the institution
REENHOlSh
The hospital is very much in need of a greeuhou
is no place to keep the plants ex
pf on the wards in th
win
mil the florist is handicapped in his spring planting by not hi
ng a suitable place to start the plain
1 wish to express my appreciation of the interest and tid
>f the officers of the institution. Our personal and olti
a
lions have been of a most pleasant Character, and the present
condition of the hospital is the best commentary p<
efficiency of their service. XI v thanks are also due to the <
pluyees who have been so faithful in the performs
trying duties
We are under obligations to the inauv editors of the state «
have so kindly sent their papers gratuitously lo tht
ill so to the ministers of the citv who have ever be<
assist in the religiouR wants of the hospital. In closing tliis report. I wish to express uiy sense
In closing this report. I wish
o expre
to the Him. Governor, \Y. A. Poynter. and the Houo
to the Ron. Governor, W. A. Povnter. and the Hoik
of Public Lands and Buildings, who have assisted
f Public Lands and Buildings, who hav
wise counsel and co-operation, which has been of
wise counsel and co-operation, which lias bee
advantage in the conduct of affairs. Hospitals of tl
among the noblest charities to which humanity can be devoted
and therefore, have the highest claims on public benevolent
and with the continued blessing of Providence, we have full
faith in its future usefulness and ability We have full conti

INSANE HOSPITAL. NORFOLK.
243
dence that wise provision will hereafter be made to meet every demaad that ran be imposed upon the state to aid in the restoration of the diseased minds of even its most humble and unfortunate citizens, and that our institution may continue to be a source of pride to the people of the state, and of pardonable
tkatioii to ourselv
Respectfully submitted
Superintendent.
